ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Good comprehensive intro to American literary canon; prof made effort to include and really dive into less-studied literary traditions with broad approach to what constitutes America focus on Black and Indigenous authors
Lots of close reading and textual analysis!
I feel like I really improved my writing this semester.
I improved as a writer. I developed skills in how to broaden and deepen my argument in its conclusion
I learned how to develop arguments based off of evidence from texts, structure coherent and streamlined essays, and hold meaningful discussions with classmates in seminars.
I hadnt read any of the books on the curriculum before, so it was interesting to get to discuss them.
I learned how to analyze texts, perform close readings, and write essays about those close readings

I learned an incredible amount about American history through the lens of American writers. I have a newfound passion of poetry (thanks to this course) and loved the interesting perspectives of the writers.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: More diverse syllabus

I think this course is taught very well, and I really enjoyed it. No weaknesses. I would say there was some suggestion to get rid of Whitman and Dickinson from the course but I strongly disagree with that, they should stay.
The strengths of this course are Professor Homans' expertise and the curriculum chosen, which spanned from Beloved to Natasha Trethewey. In terms of improvement, I think it was excellent as is.

I thought the curriculum was very interesting, as were some of the discussions surrounding it. There were some points where I think the conversations got stuck on more surface level points or geared themselves towards binary debates (e.g. is she good/bad) rather than immediately diving into the text.

Strengths: well prompted discussion
Weaknesses: too much reading which leads to surface-level discussion due to inability to truly engage with the texts

Strengths were the discussions, the reading list, the professor. I loved the class discussions, I always enjoyed them and was very engaged. I enjoyed the reading list, though I think a little less time could've been spent on Dickinson and Whitman. I loved the professor, she is amazing. She was very helpful and led the class very well.

Strengths- thoughtful and meticulous organization, flexibility, and care
Weaknesses- extensive reading

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, for English majors OR for kids who want to read more books in a semester
Yes, Professor Homans is so so lovely and the readings are very interesting.
Yes  its a great foundational English course especially for potential majors

I would recommend this course to another student. The works chosen provide an in-depth look at American history that speak to one another in a dialogue. Further, Professor Homans is extremely knowledgeable and provides an amazing seminar hand of guidance.

Absolutely! Professor Homans is wonderful-- she thoughtfully led class discussions, crafted a syllabus that told a diverse story of American Lit, and always gave incredibly helpful feedback on essays.

Its an introductory course needed for the English major, so Id say its very useful for that and anyone interested in an overview of American Literature. For people who are already well acquainted and interested in the genre, however, Id say a more advanced class might be useful.

Not particularly. I very much viewed this course as necessary to the English major, and still do only view it as that. I found the material overwhelming and cannot truly think of something I took away because I was simply so focused on getting through the readings.
Yes I would, though only if they are interested in being an English major. I am an MBB major and I enjoyed this class but I don't know that other non English majors would enjoy it.
Yea! This course is an incredible way to learn more about American literature and expand your understanding of society as a whole. I adored it and loved the readings
